MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Howth, Dublin Harbour.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Marine if his attention has been drawn to the public concern at the state of Howth Harbour, Dublin 13, and in particular, the older sections which are in need of maintenance and repair; the action, if any, he proposes to take in relation to the following: (1) the restoration of the building previously occupied by Howth Yacht Club and now in the ownership of the State (2) the demolition or restoration of the old ice plant (3) the reopening of the right of way beside the old church which has been illegally closed off (4) the repair and restoration of the wall near the base of the east pier which has been closed off because of its current danger to the public (5) the provision of a new surface to the east pier (6) the cessation of illegal dumping of fish, offal and related matter on land behind the west pier which is in the ownership of the Office of Public Works; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.P: Since 1 January 1989 my Department has assumed responsibility from the Commissioners of Public Works for Howth Harbour and arrangements to declare it a Fishery Harbour Centre, in accordance with the Fishery Harbour Centres Act, 1968-80, are in train.

I understand that Howth Harbour has been generally well maintained up to now and ongoing maintenance of the harbour will continue as part of the arrangements for maintenance of major fishery harbours under my Department's control.
As regards to the specific items raised by the Deputy, the position is as follows:
1. Tender documents to enable a lease of the premises to be advertised are being prepared, in consultation with the Chief State Solicitor. The matter will be finalised as soon as possible.
2. The principal terms of a lease of the old ice plant to a tenant have been agreed and in accordance with those terms the tenant will be required to renovate the property.

3. The passageway in question was temporarily closed off by an adjoining tenant. At the time he was advised by the Commissioners of Public Works that, when requested, he will be required to remove the hoarding. It is not considered in the interests of public safety to have it removed at present.

MainHeading.P: 4. The wall at the end of the East Pier is the responsibility of Dublin County Council. The council was notified of its condition when it first began to deteriorate.

5. A significant section of the East Pier was resurfaced following the development scheme. Resurfacing of a further section of the pier will be considered in the light of funds available for such works. I am advised that maintenance of the deck of the pier is attended to on an ongoing basis.

6. While there have been problems with the dumping of fish offal, the fish processors on the West Pier have now made arrangements to have such material stored on their premises for subsequent removal from the harbour area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - European Charter of Local Self-Government.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if his attention has been drawn to the European Charter of Local Self-Government; and if, agreeing to the principles of the charter, he will recommend to the Government that Ireland should sign the charter; the steps which would be necessary at national level by way of legislative changes to enable Ireland to ratify the Charter for Local Self-Government; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: The European Charter of Local Self-Government was drawn up within the Council of Europe on the basis of a draft proposed by the Standing Conference of Local and Regional Authorities of Europe. It was opened to signature as a convention by the member states of the Council of Europe in October 1985 and entered into force on 1 September 1988. The charter is the first multilateral legal instrument to define the principles of local autonomy.

As the Deputy will be aware, since becoming Minister I have been conducting an intensive review of the local government system in Ireland with a view to devising an appropriate package of measures which together will form the basis of a coherent and comprehensive reorganisation programme. Work on the reorganisation programme is now well advanced. When this reorganisation has been completed, full consideration will be given to the question of signing and ratifying the charter taking into account all the implications such a decision would entail.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Section 84 of the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, provides for consultation between State authorities and planning authorities prior to the construction or extension of buildings by State authorities. If there are any unresolved objections by the planning authority to the works proposed, section 84 provides for the State authority to consult on the objection with the Minister. asked the Minister for the Environment if his attention has been drawn to a proposal to extend the Southern Cross motorway to link Merrion Strand with Fosters Avenue; if his attention has further been drawn to the fact that the motorway would pass through Castle Court housing estate, Booterstown Avenue, County Dublin; that it would intrude on the Booterstown Marshes; the action he intends to ensure that all interests will be consulted in advance of the project; and if he will make an order to ensure that the marshes will be protected in all the circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: I am aware that the local authority concerned, Dún Laoghaire Corporation, are considering a road reservation on the lands in question. asked the Minister for the Environment the present position regarding the local authority's decision to go ahead with the siting of a tip-head in Dunmore. County Kilkenny without carrying out an environmental impact report in accordance with his Department's circular P.D. 111/8/20 and EC Directive 85/337.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Responsibility for the planning, organisation, authorisation and supervision of waste disposal operations in its functional area is a matter for Kilkenny County Council. I understand that the proposal to site a tip-head at Dunmore is still under consideration by the local authority.

In so far as EC Directive 85/337 and Circular P.D. 111/8/20 are concerned, the position is that it is a matter for the local authority to assess whether or not this type of project should be subjected to an environmental impact assessment, in the light of its effect on the environment and having regard to such factors as the nature, size and location of the project. An environmental impact assessment is required where a project of this nature is likely to have a significant effect on the environment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Death in Hospital.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make a statement on the death of a person (details supplied) in County Tipperary; if he has received a report on the incident; the response he had made to the Galway Simon Community on the matter; and if there will be a full investigation into the death in question.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the investigations which have been held into the circumstances of the death of a person (detailed supplied) in the casual unit of the Hospital of the Assumption, Thurles, County Tipperary, on 3 June 1988; the findings of any such investigation; if the casual unit was a locked ward; if so, the period for which it was locked; if there was any system which allowed residents to attract outside attention in the event of anyone becoming ill or the outbreak of fire; if his attention has been drawn to reports that other residents attempted to attract medical attention for the person when he became ill but were unable to do so; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 227 and 248 together. I would like to assure the Deputies that this matter has been fully investigated by the Mid-Western Health Board in conjunction with the staff at the Hospital of the Assumption, Thurles. The patient in question was treated in the hospital itself on a number of occasions and had discharged himself against medical advice some 24 hours before his death. Medical opinion indicated that because of the seriousness of his illness he could have died at any time.

I should state that the casual unit at the hospital was not a medical facility. The unit was inspected regularly by a night attendant during the night of Mr. Broderick's death. Its purpose was to provide overnight accommodation for homeless men.

MainHeading.P: The board's officials are satisfied that conditions in the casual unit at Thurles were not a factor in the patient's death. Nevertheless they felt that, in the light of this sad incident, it was necessary to carry out a full review of the arrangements for homeless people in the area. Accordingly, they have asked the Simon Community in Galway and local voluntary groups to forward proposals concerning the provision of appropriate alternative accommodation for the homeless in Thurles.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make a statement in relation to reports in the Irish Medical Times that AIDS deaths are not being reported to his Department; and the steps he proposes to take to ensure that all AIDS death are reported to his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: To date in this country 77 cases of full AIDS and 34 deaths have been reported to my Department. Dr. J.H. Walsh, National AIDS Co-ordinator, is in contact with the doctors clinically responsible for these cases and he is notified when a death occurs. In addition scans of death certificates are carried out periodically to ensure that cases are not missed. I am satisfied, in the circumstances, that everything is being done to ensure full reporting of AIDS deaths and that the current reporting system is working effectively.

The State agencies under my aegis, which are involved in overseas services on a consultancy basis are the Blood Transfusion Service Board and An Bord Altranais. In the case of the Blood Transfusion Service Board it has been exploring links with other similar type agencies in order to develop overseas services on a consultancy basis. In this regard, it has made a specific offer to assist a Middle Eastern country in developing its staff and services and it is awaiting a response from the country concerned. In the case of An Bord Altranais it has been involved in this area for a number of years. It is currently providing training courses, both specialist and general, for nurses from a number of Middle Eastern countries including Bahrain, Oman, Kuwait and Qatar. Their most recent contract involves provision of specialist nurse training in Ireland for students from Malaysia. The total value of these contracts is estimated at £150,000 in the current year.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence the date on which the 12 per cent pay award will be made to the Permanent Defence Force; the dates of application of the new allowances; and if the terms of the Programme for National Recovery as negotiated by the ICTU for the public service will apply to the Permanent Defence Force as a separate increase or if it will be incorporated into the 12 per cent special pay award.
asked the Minister for Defence the full term of the inter-departmental committee report on its review of pay and allowances for the Permanent Defence Force.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Noonan, Limerick West) Michael J. (Limerick West) Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick West): I propose to take Questions Nos. 250 and 251 together.

1. The Government have accepted all the recommendations in the report of the Inter-departmental Committee on Defence Forces Pay, Allowances and Conditions with one small amendment — the date for the payment of the increase in military service allowance. That increase will now be paid in two phases from 1 January 1989 and 1 July 1989 instead of in a single phase from 1 January 1989. The increases in all other allowances are payable in full from 1 January 1989.

P.i: Overall increase of 19 per cent for Non-Commissioned Ranks

Speaker.P: 2. Non-commissioned ranks as a whole are getting an increase of 19 per cent, made up of an increase of 12 per cent in basic pay and significant improvements in a range of allowances. This is significantly greater than what they would have got under traditional pay relationships. In addition, all the general pay increases provided for in the Programme for National Recovery and the Public Service Pay Agreement are being paid.

MainHeading.P: 3. Officers who have not benefited from recent special awards are getting an increase ranging from 10 per cent to 16 per cent when account is taken of the improvements in basic pay and in military service allowance. These officers are also benefiting from the increases in security allowances and from the general increases referred to in the previous paragraph.

4. It is not possible to pay the increases in basic pay in one phase without breaching the Public Service Pay Agreement and undermining the Programme for National Recovery. These increases will be paid on the same phased basis as for other public service groups, i.e. 40 per cent of the increases in basic pay with effect from 1 July 1989, subject to the terms of the Public Service pay Agreement.

5. The combined effect of the general increases and the increases in allowances will be to improve the average weekly pay of non-commissioned ranks by nearly 9 per cent from 1 January 1989. Payment of the increases is being made today.
6. The total cost of the full award will amount to £25.7 million a year. The 1989 cost will be £12.5 million, against which certain savings from rationalisation will be offset.
7. Promotions will be made where the Minister for Defence is satisfied after consultation with the Chief of Staff that the vacancies should be filled because of military and security considerations.
8. Examples of the amounts of the increases are shown below together with details of the various revised rates of pay and allowances.
9. The other matters which were recommended by the committee and approved by the Government are as follows:
(a) Revised rates of retirement gratuities for NCOs and Privates; Increase from 21 to 25 week's pay at 21 years' service and to a maximum of 45 weeks' pay at 31 years' service.
(b) Revised rates payable on discharge by purchase: Top rate to be increased from £1,200 to £5,000 and other rates to be adjusted also.
(c) Review of the rate of deduction for rations: The current rate is £1.68 per day in respect of three meals.

(d) Future pay Reviews: Two former members of the Permanent Defence Force will be appointed, following consultation with the military authorities, to the inter-departmental committee established in June 1988 which will continue in existence.

(e) Rationalisation of the network of military barracks and posts throughout the country involving the immediate closure and disposal of military barracks, including Griffith and Collins Barracks, Dublin, and other properties which are surplus to security requirements.

Speaker.P: The question of assistance for a resource centre for the unemployed is not a matter for my Department. Accordingly, it is not open to me to consider allocating a grant in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Repeat Leaving Certificate Fee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding payment of £100 fee for a repeat leaving certificate in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Cork who is a medical card holder.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: As the person named is the holder of a current medical card she will be exempted from the repeat leaving certificate course fee and will be liable to pay only the normal examination fee (£35) applicable to first time candidates. Arrangements are being made to refund the £100 already paid in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Early School Leavers Project.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the special education project for early school leavers at a school (details supplied) in Dublin 7; if she has received any request for financial assistance for the project; if she can assist the project in any way; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The school authorities did indicate in late 1988 their interest in Youthreach — the new scheme for unqualified early school leavers being mounted on behalf of the Departments of Education and Labour. Provision of programmes under the scheme will be the responsibility of agencies of these Departments, respectively the VECs and FÁS.

I understand that while the school has confirmed its interest in the scheme to the City of Dublin VEC it does not wish to run a programme in 1989 but would wish to co-operate with the VEC in identifying likely participants. The VEC is maintaining contact with the school regarding its interest in the scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when her Department will issue an authorisation to County Kildare Vocational Education Committee and County Dublin Vocational Education Committee to implement the findings of the public service arbitrator regarding the salary scales of teachers employed by those committees in the Army Apprentice School, Naas, County Kildare and the Air Corps School, Baldonnell, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The authorisation to which the Deputy refers was issued by my Department to the relevant vocational education committees on 9 January 1989.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Capital Moneys for Sport Organisations.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education, in respect of the capital moneys which were made available through her Department including national lottery money for facilitating sports organisations with the construction of sports facilities, if she will indicate (a) the total amount of money that was allocated to various organisations in 1988 and (b) the total amount of money that has not been taken up and which remains unspent; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: It is assumed the Deputy is referring to the capital grants scheme for the provision of recreational facilities. The entire 1988 allocation of £4 million has been allocated to projects under the scheme. The sum of £1,689,245 was disbursed to grantees by 31 December 1988. The balance of the £4 million will be expended according as construction projects are completed, in the case of each grantee, and the various requirements of the scheme are complied with in full.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the second level schools for which new buildings have been provided in each of the past two years; and the specific needs which existed in each case which justified this provision.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education (a) the number of existing or newly established post-primary schools for which new buildings of substantial cost, that is over £100,000 were provided in the years (a) in 1985 (b) 1986 (c) 1987 and (d) 1988; the names of such schools; and the present enrolment of such schools as indicated in their most recent returns to her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 282 and 283 together. The detailed information sought by the Deputy needs to be compiled and the time available to my Department is not adequate for this purpose. Accordingly I will write to him in due course with the information required.

As regards the existence of need for new accommodation a written reply which I made to him on 15 November 1988 sets out the main criteria governing the provision of new buildings for existing or newly established post-primary schools. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - State Agencies Overseas Services.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy in respect of the State agencies directly under his aegis, the action which they have taken to establish a five-year development plan to develop overseas services on a consultancy basis relating to the skills and experience of the State agency; and if he will make a statement on the matter indicating (a) the number of contracts, if any, which have been obtained and (b) the approximate value of the work which has been obtained.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Smith) Minister for Energy (Mr. Smith)
Speaker.P: The position with regard to the development of overseas consultancy services in relation to the State-sponsored bodies under my aegis is as follows:
BGE is at present reviewing proposals for a five year plan. To date BGE has negotiated one contract which has an approximate value of £40,000.

MainHeading.P: Bord na Móna has no authority under existing legislation to engage in consultancy work. The Turf Development Bill, 1988, which is currently before the Dáil, includes provisions designed to enable the board to develop consultancy services, where appropriate. Bord na Móna personnel, on secondment to the Department of Foreign Affairs, have participated in overseas bog development projects.

The ESB is engaged in a major expansion of its overseas consultancy operations via its newly formed subsidiary ESB International Ltd. Its aim is to provide employment for 500 people with an annual turnover of £50 million by 1992. To date ESB International Ltd. has secured a total of 86 contracts valued at approximately £10 million.

INPC's activities are centred on the operation of the Whitegate Refinery whose output is restricted to the quantities required under the Fuels Order, 1983. However, their subsidiary company, Irish Refining Plc., has secured two overseas consultancy contracts to the value of £40,000 per annum.
As the Nuclear Energy Board is still engaged in setting up monitoring programmes in Ireland there is little scope at present for developing overseas consultancy services.
Coillte Teoranta, the State Forestry Company, has only been operational since 1 January this year and has not as yet developed any plans in this area.
